Graphical abstract The orderly developed mesoporous structure extremely facilitates the reactant and product molecules to move throngh the MnO x -HT catalyst, which is very benetful to the PVOCs combustion. The aggreated bulk structure badly handicaps the movement and transfer of the reactant and product molecules through the MnO x -PC catalyst, thus go against the PVOCs combustion. The PVOCs catalytic combustion over both MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts follows Mars Van Krevelen mechanism, the PVOC molecules are adsorbed and activated on the catalyst surface, and then react with the reactive oxygen species on the catalyst surface to form CO2 and H2O to realize PVOC molecules complete combustion. As the reactive oxygen species comsumed, the molecular oxygen can be adsorbed and activated on the catalyst surface to form reacttive oxygen species, and it can also be effectively supplied by the lattice oxygen. After the lattice oxygen converts to the reactive oxygen species being comsumed, the adsorbed oxygen species on the catalyst surface can convert to supply it in time. In this study, manganese oxide (MnO x ) catalysts were prepared by using hard-template (MnO x -HT) and precipitation (MnO x -PC) methods. The prepared MnO x catalysts were systematically characterized by XRD, TEM, BET, XPS, O2-TPD, and H2-TPR analyses. The activity of the catalysts was investigated in the catalytic combustion of PVOCs, such as benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene, in air. Results indicate that the chemical composition and structure of the prepared MnO x oxide catalysts are obviously affected by the preparation methods. The T 90 corresponding to the catalytic combustion of xylene, ethylbenzene, toluene, and the T 60 of benzene over the MnO x -HT catalyst are 200°C, 205°C, 210°C, and 225°C, which are much lower than that over MnO x -PC. The catalytic combustion of the PVOCs over the MnO x -HT catalyst follows the order xylene>ethylbenzene>toluene>benzene. Both the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts exhibit stable catalytic performance during the combustion of toluene. Therefore, the superior catalytic performance of the MnO x -HT catalyst can be attributed to the high MnO2 content, high concentration of surface reactive oxygen, highly ordered mesopores, large specific surface area, good oxygen mobility, and low-temperature reducibility. In addition, the catalytic combustion of the phenyl compounds is affected by their inherent characteristics such as structural stability, molecular polarity, and dimensions. Keywords Manganese oxide catalyst Ordered mesoporous structure Catalytic combustion PVOCs 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are a class of organic compounds characterized by high vapor pressure at room temperature, due to which they tend to readily evaporate or sublimate. They are among the most harmful air pollutants and have deleterious effects on the environment and human health. Among the different VOCs, the phenyl volatile organic compounds (PVOCs) such as benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene are categorized by the World Health Organization to be chronic toxic substances and violent carcinogens [1–3]. These stable compounds are being extensively used in several fields, such as the petrochemical, motor fuel, paint, plastic, medical, steel, and detergent industries. To address the concerns associated with VOCs, several countries have introduced legislations to reduce the emission of VOCs and to restrict their concentration level in air [2]. On January 1, 2006, the European Union changed the regulation on the average concentration limit of benzene in air from 5μgm−3 to 1μgm−3. According to the World Health Organization, the average exposure concentration limit of toluene in the atmosphere is 8.21μgm−3 [3]. Driven by this critical situation, there has been a considerable interest worldwide on the control and removal of PVOCs. Thus far, several techniques such as direct combustion, plasma oxidation, and photocatalytic oxidation, have been proposed and developed for mitigating the issues related to VOCs. Among them, catalytic combustion is considered to be a very competitive treatment technique, in terms of its high purification efficiency and low energy consumption, for transforming the VOCs into CO2, H2O, and other non-toxic or less toxic compounds. In particular, catalytic combustion is considered one of the most effective treatment methods for the removal of low-concentration (<1.0% in volume) phenyl compounds from air [4], making it a research hotspot in environmental catalysis. The core issue in this process is the design and development of catalytic materials. In recent years, noble metals have been extensively studied as catalysts owing to their high activity for the catalytic combustion of low concentrations of VOCs in the atmosphere [5–7]. However, the wide applicability of these noble catalytic materials is greatly limited by its high cost, limited availability, and low CO2 selectivity at low reaction temperatures. In addition to noble metals, transition metal oxides are also attracting great attentions as catalysts owing to the their low cost, high resistance to common poisons, and comparable activity towards the catalytic combustion of VOCs in air [8,9]. However, transition metal oxide catalysts synthesized by conventional preparation methods have small specific surface area (<30m2 g−1), low porosity, irregular pore size distribution, and non-adjustable chemical composition, which lead to weak adsorption and low activation of the reactant molecules [10–12]. Ordered mesoporous transition-metal oxides have emerged as a new class of functional materials with unique physicochemical properties originating due to the confinement of D-shell electrons within the nano-sized pore walls, internal surfaces with redox properties, developed mesoporous network, large specific surface area, and well-dispersed composition [13–16]. However, compared with the siliceous materials, realizing an ordered mesoporous structure is rather challenging in transition metal oxides. This is because the transition metal oxides are much more susceptible to hydrolysis, redox reactions, and phase transitions. Lately, some non-siliceous mesoporous metal oxides have been prepared by using soft organic surfactants templates. Nonetheless, highly crystalline mesoporous metal oxides could not be obtained due to the low calcination temperatures (high temperatures would result in a structural collapse) [17]. More recently, hard template method using ordered mesoporous silica template has gained considerable interest as potential alternative to the conventional methods. Thus far, several ordered mesoporous transition metal oxides with high crystallinity, including Cr2O3, Co3O4, CeCuO x , and MnO x , have been successfully synthesized using KIT-6 or SBA-15 as hard templates [13–16]. Among them, ordered mesoporous manganese oxides (MnO x ) are considered as environmentally friendly and cheap catalytic materials, which show high activity towards the oxidation of naphthalene, tetraethylated rhodamine, toluene, and CO, because of the highly efficient redox cycling [18–20]. Besides, they offer the advantage of controlling the surface composition via adept control of the preparation methods. However, the use of ordered mesoporous MnO x catalysts for the catalytic elimination of volatile phenyl compounds (especially, xylene, ethylbenzene, and benzene) from air is rarely reported in the literature. Therefore, given the potentials of ordered mesoporous MnO x catalysts for the catalytic combustion of phenyl compounds, a comprehensive study in this perspective is expected to have significant environmental implications. To this end, this study aims to synthesize manganese oxide (MnO x ) catalysts with different physicochemical properties, and assess their catalytic activity towards the elimination of various PVOCs, including benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene, from air. The prepared MnO x catalysts are characterized by using X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD), and H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analyses. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In the typical synthesis of mesoporous MnO x catalyst by the hard-template method, 1.0g of 50% Mn(NO3)2 solution was dissolved in 20mL of ethanol. Subsequently, KIT-6 mesoporous silica template was added to the reaction solution. The silica template was prepared according to the procedure described by Ryoo et al. [21]. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature until a dry powder was obtained, followed by drying at 100°C for 24h. The powder thus obtained was heated to 400°C at the heating rate of 5°C/min and calcinated at that temperature for 2.0h. The impregnation and drying procedure was repeated, followed by calcination at 500°C for 3h. The resulting sample was treated thrice with 2M NaOH to remove the silica template. Afterwards, the sample was centrifuged, and washed several times with water and ethanol. Finally, the sample was air-dried at 100°C for 24h. The Mn-oxide sample thus obtained was designated as MnO x -HT. In addition to the above method, MnO x catalysts were also prepared by precipitation method. In the typical process, 50% Mn(NO3)2 solution was dissolved in a certain amount of deionized water. Subsequently, dilute ammonia was added dropwise to the aqueous Mn(NO3)2 solution under stirring at room temperature, until the pH of the solution reached about 9. The resulting mixture was left undisturbed for two days. The resulting precipitate was centrifuged, and washed several times with water. Finally, the sample was air-dried at 100°C, followed by calcination at 500°C for 3h. The Mn-oxide catalyst thus obtained was designated as MnO x -PC. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 XRD analysis The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500/PC diffractometer with a rotating anode using Ni filtered Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.15418nm) at a tube voltage of 40kV and a tube current of 200mA. The 2θ data were collected in the range of 20°–80° with the step size of 0.02° and at the rate of 5°/min. 2.2.2 TEM analysis The morphology of the prepared samples was observed using a Tecnai G2 Spirit transmission electron microscope (TEM) operating with an acceleration voltage of 120kV. For the TEM observation, the samples were first dispersed in ethanol under ultrasonication, followed by evaporation onto a carbon-coated copper grid. 2.2.3 BET characterization The adsorption–desorption isotherms of the samples were collected on Autosorb-6 at −196°C. Prior to the measurement, the samples were degassed at 200°C until a stable vacuum of ca. 5mTorr was reached. From adsorption data, the specific surface area was assessed using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range of 0.06–0.10. Besides, the total pore volume, V t, was assessed from the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99, by converting it to the corresponding volume of liquid adsorbate. 2.2.4 XPS characterization The chemical states of Mn and O in the prepared MnO x catalysts were determined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS signals were collected using a KRATOS X-ray source with an aluminum crystal, operating at an anode voltage of 12kV and emission current of 12mA to generate the required Al Kα radiation. Subsequently, curve fitting and background subtraction were performed using Casa XPS software. 2.2.5 O2-TPD studies The O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) study of the samples was conducted using a conventional apparatus equipped with a TCD detector. In the typical process, 100mg of the sample was placed in a quartz tube (4.0mm ID), which was pre-treated with air at 250°C for 30min. After the sample was cooled down to room temperature, TPD was performed by heating the sample from 30 to 600°C in He atmosphere at the heating rate of 10°C/min and He flow rate of 25mL/min. 2.2.6 TPR studies The H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted using a conventional apparatus equipped with a TCD detector. In the typical process, 15mg of the sample was placed in a quartz tube (4.0mm ID). Subsequently, TPR was performed by heating the samples from 30 to 700°C at the heating rate of at 10°C/min, in the presence of 5% H2–N2 mixture flowing at the rate of 25mL/min. 2.3 Determination of catalytic activity The catalytic performance of the samples was estimated using a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (ID 6mm) operated under atmospheric pressure. In the typical process, the quartz tube reactor containing 50mg of the catalyst was placed inside a tubular furnace. Subsequently, air was passed downward through the reactor containing the catalyst bed. During this process, the flow rate of the air was controlled using an electronic mass flow controller (D07-7A/ZM, China). The feed gas was obtained by bubbling air through a saturator, which contained the volatile phenyl compounds (including benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene) in liquid phase. The saturator was maintained at a certain temperature to achieve the feed gas mixture consisting of gaseous phenyl compounds (1.0vol.%). The feed gas thus generated was passed over the catalyst at a flow rate of 55mL/min, equivalent to the gas mass space velocity of 66,000mLg−1 h−1. The catalytic activity test was performed in the temperature range of 180–300°C, which was measured using a thermocouple projecting into the catalyst bed. The reaction temperature was monitored using a temperature programmable controller (ÜGU, model 708P, China) at a heating rate of 2°C/min, until the desired temperature is achieved. Prior to each test, the catalyst bed was heated to the pre-determined temperature at a heating rate of 10°C/min. Subsequently, the feed gas was passed through the catalyst bed and stabilized for 120min for recording the data every 5min. The quantity of organic compounds in the feed gas and the gaseous reaction products was monitored using an online gas chromatograph (GC 6890II), equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD characterization Fig. 1 shows the wide-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts, which were prepared by using hard template and precipitation methods, respectively. The XRD pattern of the MnO x -PC catalyst shows several intense and sharp diffraction peaks labeled using black solid circle, which can be attributed to the cubic spinel structure of the Mn2O3 crystalline phase [JCPDS 76-0150]. Besides, the relatively weak diffraction peaks at 21.6°, 28.8°, 37.1°, 43.0°, 67.6°, and 72.5°, correspond to the MnO2 crystalline phase [22,23]. Similarly, the XRD pattern of the MnO x -HT catalyst shows a series of weak and broad diffraction peaks at 2θ =23.3°, 33.1°, 45.2°, 49.6°, 55.2°, 58.2°, and 65.8° [JCPDS 76-0150], which are the characteristic peaks of the Mn2O3 crystalline phase with cubic spinel structure. In addition, the diffraction peaks observed at 28.8°, 37.2°, 42.7°, 56.6°, and 72.5° can be unambiguously assigned to the MnO2 crystalline phase [22,23]. These results indicate that the Mn2O3 and MnO2 crystalline phases coexist in the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts. That apart, the XRD pattern of both the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts did not show any additional peaks corresponding to other manganese oxides, such as Mn3O4 and MnO. This implies that the manganese oxides are either absent or their presence is below the detectability limit of the XRD. Although both the MnO x -PC and MnO x -HT catalysts have Mn2O3 and MnO2 crystalline phases, the diffraction peaks are apparently distinct in terms of the peak intensity. The XRD pattern of the MnO x -PC catalyst shows several sharp and high-intensity peaks of Mn2O3 crystalline phase, together with weak diffraction peaks corresponding to the MnO2 crystalline phase. This implies that a large amount of Mn2O3 species coexists with relatively small amount of MnO2 species. On the other hand, the XRD peaks of the MnO x -HT catalyst are relatively weak and broader. This is typically indicative of a well-dispersed condition or/and low content. This demonstrates that a greater proportion of MnO2 species and fewer Mn2O3 species exist in the MnO x -HT catalyst, when compared to that in the MnO x -PC catalyst. Besides, the weak and wide XRD peaks also indicate that the MnO2 and Mn2O3 species are well dispersed in the prepared MnO x -HT catalyst, and a part of them may exist in the amorphous state. In general, different MnO x or the same MnO x in different phases can lead to different physicochemical properties, such as surface reactive oxygen content, oxygen mobility, and reducibility [19,24]. The low-angle XRD peak of the MnO x -PC catalyst, shown in the illustration in Fig. 1, is not observed in the range from 0.5° to 5.0°. However, the low-angle XRD of the MnO x -HT catalyst shows a sharp intense peak the same as the used KIT-6 template at 2θ =0.93° (the {211} plane), but it is broad and low in intensity. Previous studies reported in the literature have demonstrated that the hard template silica can be almost completely removed by treating twice or thrice with 2M NaOH solution [13,18]. Thus, the MnO x -HT catalyst prepared in this study has an ordered mesoporous structure, indicating a good negative replica of the ordered mesoporous KIT-6 template, although there is relative decrease in the orderliness [9,14,21,25]. This demonstrates a significant advancement to the catalysts prepared by traditional methods. Besides, it indicates the potential application of the prepared MnO x -HT catalyst for the catalytic combustion VOCs, as the ordered porous structure theoretically facilitates the transition and movement of the reactant VOCs and the resulting gaseous products in the gas–solid reaction system [9,14]. 3.2 TEM analysis The TEM images of the prepared MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The MnO x -HT catalyst exhibits a developed porous structure with a pore size and pore wall size of approximately 11.0nm and 9.0nm, respectively, as clearly observed from the inset shown in Fig. 2. On the other hand, the TEM image of the MnO x -PC catalyst shows an overlapped and aggregated structure. In other words, the particles stick very closely to each other and form large particles with distinct shapes and sizes. The minimum particle size of the MnO x -PC catalyst exceeds 100nm, as determined by measuring the particles located at the edge of the catalyst. Besides, the porous structure is not observed on the large particles. According to Fig. 2, the used hard template KIT-6 reportedly exhibits a three-dimensional, symmetrically ordered mesoporous structure, namely, the ordered cubic Ia3D structural symmetry [21,25]. During the preparation of the catalyst, the KIT-6 template used in the process determines the formation of porous structure and pore size adjustment [13–15]. As evidenced from the TEM image shown in Fig. 2, the structure of the MnO x -HT catalyst is an excellent negative replica of the ordered structure of KIT-6, consistent with the low-angle XRD results. Compared with the aggregated and bulk structure of the MnO x -PC catalyst, the ordered porous structure of the MnO x -HT catalyst with the pore size of about 11nm can facilitate the exposure of more atoms (with uneven force) on the surface of the catalyst. The exposed atoms on the solid surface have different local environment, compared with the atoms in the bulk. This local environment is the driving force for many physicochemical processes, such as the adsorption of reactant molecules on the surface of the catalyst [26]. Moreover, the ordered mesoporous structure of the MnO x -HT catalyst can significantly facilitate the movement and diffusion of the reactant molecules in the pores, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the catalyst [14]. In nutshell, the observed difference in the structure of the prepared samples can result in different physicochemical properties and catalytic performance. 3.3 BET characterization Furthermore, the pore structure and specific surface area of the prepared MnO x -HT, MnO x -PC catalysts, and the using template KIT-6 was determined from the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 3 ), in order to explore the role of the hard template KIT-6. In Fig. 2, the using KIT-6 template shows a type IV isotherm with H1 hysteresis, characteristic of mesoporous silica materials [21]. It also has a large specific surface area of 738m2 g−1 and very narrow pore size distribution with only one peak centered at about 6.5nm (illustration). The MnO x -HT catalyst exhibits a type-IV isotherm, which is typical of a mesoporous transition metal oxide prepared by the hard-template method [9,13–16]. Differing with that of the using template, this isotherm displays several prominent characteristics. Within a relatively low-pressure range (p/p 0 <0.5), the adsorption of the sample is limited to a single molecular layer without hysteresis. In the p/p 0 range of 0.5–0.75, the adsorption curve changes to a convex shape, slowly separating from the desorption curve. This indicates the high affinity of the adsorbates onto the surface of the MnO x -HT catalyst in this particular pressure range. In the p/p 0 range of 0.7–0.98, the adsorption isotherm shows a sudden and drastic change, attributable to the capillary condensation, as the adsorption of the nitrogen molecules increases sharply [18]. At the same time, the N2 desorption isotherm does not increase corresponding to the adsorption isotherm. This results in a type-H3 hysteresis within the studied pressure range. Such an isotherm is mainly observed in catalysts with the different pore structure [27]. These features demonstrate that the MnO x -HT catalyst prepared by using the KIT-6 template has a mesoporous structure. As shown in the illustration, the pore distribution of the MnO x -HT catalyst shows two peaks centered at approximately 3.6 and 12.7nm, respectively, which is obviously wider than that of the using KIT-6. And the peak centered at larger pore diameter is much higher in intensity comparing with the one centered at lower pore diameter, which indicates most of meso-pores of the MnO x -HT catalyst having diameter about 12.7nm. This result is consistent with the TEM observation. Besides, the specific surface area of the MnO x -HT catalyst, as calculated by using the BET equation, is as high as 87.9m2 g−1. On the other hand, in case of the MnO x -PC catalyst, the adsorption–desorption isotherms are almost straight lines, coinciding with each other in the p/p 0 range of 0.0–1.0. The N2 adsorption capacity is found to be as low as 12.5mLg−1, even at p/p 0 of 1.0. This demonstrates that the catalyst has a very weak affinity towards the adsorbed N2 gas molecules. The specific surface area of the MnO x -PC catalyst, as calculated by using the BET method, is as low as 8.15m2 g−1. Combining with the TEM results, it can be confirmed that the MnO x -PC catalyst has an overlapped bulk structure with low porosity and low specific surface area. Hence, the MnO x -PC catalyst barely has any exposed atoms and uneven forces on its surface. Consequently, the MnO x -PC catalyst has relatively low amount of MnO2 and surface-adsorbed oxygen species when compared with the MnO x -HT catalyst, consistent with the XRD and XPS results. This may be attributed to the strong adsorption capacity of the MnO x -HT catalyst towards the oxygen molecules, which facilitates the oxidation of Mn2O3 species to produce MnO2 species at corresponding calcination temperature during the catalyst preparation process. 3.4 XPS characterization Fig. 4 shows the XPS spectra of the prepared catalysts. The Mn 2p XPS spectra of the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts shown in Fig. 4a exhibit two similar XPS peaks. However, upon deconvolution, two distinct peaks could be observed. In the Mn 2p spectra, the two peaks at 641.4 and 643.0eV correspond to the Mn3+ and Mn4+ states, respectively, which are attributed to Mn2O3 and MnO2 species, respectively [19,28]. This result substantiates the coexistence of MnO2 and Mn2O3 oxides on the surface of the prepared MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts, consistent with the XRD results. Furthermore, comparing the intensity of the deconvoluted peaks, the Mn3+ peak of the MnO x -HT catalyst is relatively weaker than that of the MnO x -PC catalyst, while the Mn4+ peak of the MnO x -HT catalyst is sharper and more intense than that of the MnO x -PC catalyst. Quantitative analysis showing the percentage of the Mn3+ and Mn4+ states in the samples is presented in Table 1 . As is seen, the percentage of the Mn3+ and Mn4+ species in the MnO x -PC catalyst is 80.8% and 19.2%, respectively, while that in the MnO x -HT catalyst is 46.5% and 53.5%, respectively. This suggests the presence of relatively higher percentage of MnO2 species on the surface of the MnO x -HT catalyst. Besides, the existence of the Mn4+/Mn3+ ion pair is conducive for the formation and transfer of active oxygen species in the corresponding catalyst. The MnO x catalysts prepared in this study exhibit asymmetrical O 1s spectra, as shown in Fig. 4b. Upon deconvolution, the O1s spectra show three peaks at the binding energies of 529.5, 531.1 and 532.8eV. The oxygen species at the lowest binding energy (ca. 529.5eV) is assigned to the lattice oxygen (OLatt). The peak at 531.1eV is characteristic of the hydroxyl oxygen (OOH), taking forms of hydroxyl OH− and carbonate CO2− species. The peak with the highest binding energy (ca. 532.8eV) can be assigned to the surface-adsorbed oxygen (OAds) [29,30]. Furthermore, it can be observed that the surface-adsorbed oxygen peak (ca. 532.8eV) of the MnO x -HT catalyst is broader and stronger than that of the MnO x -PC catalyst. This suggests the high quantity of adsorbed oxygen species in the MnO x -HT catalyst. According to the quantitative analysis presented in Table 1, the percentage of lattice oxygen (OLatt), hydroxyl oxygen (OOH), and surface-adsorbed oxygen (OAds) on the surface of the MnO x -PC catalyst is 76.8%, 17.4% and 5.7%, respectively. In case of the MnO x -HT catalyst, the percentage of hydroxyl oxygen and surface-absorbed oxygen increased to 21.6% and 11.5%, respectively. This indicates a high content of surface hydroxyl oxygen and adsorbed oxygen species in the MnO x -HT catalyst. In principle, the adsorbed oxygen is considered as the reactive oxygen species, which directly participates in the catalytic oxidation or combustion reaction at certain reaction temperature. Besides, the hydroxyl oxygen can be thermally dehydrated at certain conditions to form adsorbed oxygen species [30]. These results demonstrate that the MnO x -HT catalyst can provide more surface adsorbed oxygen for effective catalytic oxidation or combustion reaction, when compared with the MnO x -PC catalyst. Typically, a high content of surface-absorbed oxygen species is one of the key factors contributing to the high activity of the catalyst towards the catalytic oxidation or combustion of organic compounds [8,20]. Therefore, it is clear that the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts have various chemical components and surface-absorbed oxygen contents by using the different preparation methods. 3.5 TPD studies O2-TPD is an efficient method for identifying the presence and mobility of the surface oxygen species in the catalysts. The O2-TPD profiles of the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts in the range of 50–600°C are shown in Fig. 5 . In case of the MnO x -PC catalyst, the oxygen desorption curve deviates from the baseline (as shown by the arrow) at approximately 115°C, featuring four oxygen desorption peaks at 150, 230, 404, and 541°C. On contrary, the oxygen desorption curve of the MnO x -HT catalyst deviates from the baseline (as shown by the arrow) at about 51°C, showing two weak desorption peaks at 82°C and 230°C, as well as a prominent and strong desorption peak at 541°C. Moreover, the peak area and intensity of the oxygen desorption peak at 541°C is far greater than that in the MnO x -PC catalyst. It is well known that, at temperatures below 500°C, the surface physisorbed oxygen O2(ad) and the chemically adsorbed species O2 2−/O2 −/O−(ad) in the oxide catalysts tend to desorbs readily than the lattice oxygen (O2−), [31,32]. Therefore, the oxygen desorption peaks in the temperature range of 50–450°C can be described as the α-O desorption. This can be attributed to the molecular O2, O2 −/O2 2−/O−(ad) species that are chemically adsorbed on the surface or the oxygen vacancies [32]. The oxygen desorption peak above 450°C is described as the β-O desorption, which is related to the release of lattice oxygen from the oxides [31]. According to the results shown in Fig. 5, the α-O desorption in the MnO x -HT catalyst occurs below 300°C, which is far lower than that observed in the MnO x -PC catalyst. Moreover, the peak intensity and area of the β-O desorption in case of the MnO x -HT catalyst is much greater than that in case of the MnO x -PC catalyst. These results demonstrate the higher mobility and desorption ability of oxygen species in the MnO x -HT catalyst, when compared with the MnO x -PC catalyst. The lattice oxygen in the MnO x -HT catalyst readily transforms into surface reactive oxygen species to participate in the catalytic oxidation and combustion reaction [33]. The high mobility and desorption ability of the oxygen species can be attributed to well-dispersed or amorphous MnO x species formed in the MnO x -HT catalyst. Besides, the large specific surface area and orderly developed mesopores facilitate the maximal exposure of the MnO x species to the surface. Consequently, more lattice oxygen species readily desorb at around 550°C. Correlating with the XPS results, it can be realized that the MnO x -HT catalyst possesses high content of adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen species, which readily desorb to form reactive oxygen species. This, in turn, allows the catalyst to effectively provide reactive oxygen species for the combustion of VOCs. Moreover, it can be inferred that the MnO x -HT catalyst can adsorb and activate molecular O2 from air to form rich adsorbed oxygen O2 −/O− species under the reaction conditions. They tend to desorb readily, thereby replenishing the consumed reactive oxygen species during the combustion of VOCs. 3.6 TPR studies Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR spectra of the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts. As is seen, the positions of the two H2-TPR peaks, namely, α and β, are at different reduction temperatures for the prepared MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts. In case of the MnO x -PC catalyst, the consumed hydrogen signal deviates from the baseline at 225°C, as indicated by an arrow mark. At the same time, the α and β reduction peaks appear at 350 and 455°C, respectively. In case of the MnO x -HT catalyst, the consumed hydrogen signal obviously deviates from the baseline at 140°C, as shown by an arrow mark. Besides, the α and β reduction peaks of the two-step reduction temperatures shift to 280°C and 400°C, respectively. In case of the MnO x -HT catalyst, the peak intensity and area of the α peak is significantly greater than that of the β peak. This is quite different from that observed in the MnO x -PC catalyst, wherein the peak intensity and area of the α peak is significantly smaller than that of the β peak. As is well known, the distinct two-step reduction peaks in the TPR profiles are caused by the reduction of different reducible MnO x species, such as MnO2, Mn2O3, and Mn3O4 oxides. In the reduction temperature range of 100–600°C, the MnO is assumed as the final reduction state from the various Mn species in the initial state of MnO x [18,19]. Furthermore, the TPR peak temperature of the MnO x -HT catalyst is relatively lower than that of the MnO x -PC catalyst. Based on the XRD and XPS results, the relatively lower TPR peak temperature of MnO x -HT could be attributed the reduction of more MnO2 species, and the well dispersion of MnO x species in the catalyst. At the same time, the increased reducibility of the MnO x species can also be related to the ordered pore structure and high specific surface area of the MnO x -HT catalyst, consistent with the low-angle XRD, TEM, and BET results. In principle, it improves the adsorption capacity of the catalyst towards the H2 molecules and enlarges the contact area of the reducible MnO x species with the H2 molecules during the TPR process. It has been reported that the H2-TPR peak at lower temperature could be attributed to the reduction of MnO2 to form Mn2O3 or/and Mn3O4, while the peak at higher temperature corresponds to the reduction of Mn2O3 or Mn3O4 to form MnO [19,20,34]. The reduction process can be expressed as follows: MnO2 +H2 →Mn2O3 (or Mn3O4)+H2O and Mn2O3 (or Mn3O4)+H2 →MnO+H2O. Considering the stoichiometric relationship for the reduction of the mono-component MnO2, both the low-temperature and high-temperature TPR peaks should have the same peak area. In case of the two-step reduction procedure observed in the multi-component MnO x , it is reasonable to propose that the MnO2 or the well-dispersed Mn2O3 species are reduced to form Mn2O3 or Mn3O4 at low temperature. On the other hand, the reduction of the Mn2O3 or Mn3O4 species in the MnO x catalyst occurs at high reduction temperature. Therefore, if Mn2O3 exists in the MnO x sample, then the peak area of the high temperature β peak is expected to be greater than that of the low temperature α peak. According to the XRD and XPS results, the MnO2 and Mn2O3 species co-exist in the prepared MnO x -PC and MnO x -HT catalysts, with the corresponding ratio of Mn4+/Mn3+ being 0.24 and 1.15, respectively. As evidenced from the TPR spectrum shown in Fig. 5, the α and β peak areas of the MnO x -PC catalyst are 683 and 849 (a.u.), respectively, and the peak area ratio of α/β is 0.8. This suggests the low content of MnO2 species in the MnO x -PC catalyst, consistent with the XRD and XPS results. However, the coexistence of MnO2 and Mn2O3 species is also observed in the MnO x -HT catalyst, which should result in the same phenomenon observed in the MnO x -PC catalyst. On contrary, the peak area of the low temperature α peak is obviously greater than the peak area of the high temperature β peak, showing a value of 978 and 545 (a.u.), respectively. The peak area ratio of α/β is 1.79. This could be attributed to the reduction of the MnO2 and well-dispersed Mn2O3 species. In other words, a part of the well-dispersed Mn2O3 species was reduced at a low reduction temperature, resulting in larger peak area of the α peak. Therefore, the high peak area of the α peak can be attributed to the reduction of the MnO2 or well-dispersed Mn2O3 species on the surface of the MnO x -HT catalyst to form Mn2O3 or/and Mn3O4. Meanwhile, the β peak appears because of the reduction of the bulk Mn2O3 species and the Mn2O3 or/and Mn3O4 species obtained from the first-step reduction process. These results indicate that the composition and structure of the MnO x -HT catalyst contribute to its higher low-temperature reducibility, when compared to the MnO x -PC catalyst. Combining with the XPS and O2-TPD results, it can be inferred that the MnO x -HT catalyst can provide more active oxygen species for the catalytic combustion of VOCs, as its low temperature reducibility is far superior to the MnO x -PC catalyst. 3.7 Catalytic combustion of VOCs on the MnO x catalysts Fig. 7a and b shows the performance of the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts, respectively, towards the catalytic combustion of various phenyl compounds, including benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene. As evidenced from figures, both the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts exhibit high catalytic combustion activity for the phenyl compounds, with the catalytic activity of the MnO x -HT catalyst being relatively higher than the MnO x -PC catalyst. In case of the MnO x -HT catalyst, the minimum reaction temperatures at which the conversions of toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene exceed 90% (T 90) and that at which the benzene conversion exceeds 60% (T 60), are 210°C, 200°C, 205°C, and 225°C, respectively. The catalytic activity of the MnO x -HT catalyst follows the order xylene>ethylbenzene>toluene>benzene. On the other hand, the catalytic conversion of toluene on the MnO x -PC catalyst is only 73%, even at the reaction temperature of 275°C. Besides, the T 90 for toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene over the MnO x -PC catalyst is 280°C, 280°C, and 290°C, respectively. Furthermore, the T 60 for benzene over the MnO x -PC catalyst is 275°C. The catalytic activity on the MnO x -PC catalyst follows the order toluene>xylene>ethylbenzene>benzene. These results indicate that the catalytic activity of the MnO x -HT catalyst towards the combustion of phenyl compounds is obviously higher than the MnO x -PC catalyst. As is seen, both the catalysts exhibit low catalytic combustion activity towards the removal of benzene, without exceeding 70%. Nevertheless, the activity of the MnO x -HT catalyst is obviously superior to the conventional noble metals and Mn-based oxide catalysts [5–7,11–13]. These results indicate that the MnO x -HT catalyst serve as a cost-effective as well as efficient option for the elimination of PVOCs from air. According to the XRD and XPS results, MnO2 and Mn2O3 are the major oxide phases in the prepared MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts, with the MnO x -HT catalyst having a relatively higher content of MnO2 species (some of them are well dispersed or in the amorphous state). The existence of the Mn4+/Mn3+ ion pair in the catalyst can promote the activation of the reactant oxygen molecules to form active oxygen species via redox cycle. According to the XPS, O2-TPD, and TPR results, MnO x -HT has higher surface adsorbed oxygen content, oxygen desorption ability, oxygen mobility, and low-temperature reducibility, when compared with MnO x -PC. Given these advantages, the MnO x -HT catalyst can provide surplus reactive oxygen species and can readily activate the molecular O2 from air to form reactive oxygen species during the catalytic combustion process. At the same time, low-angle XRD, TEM, and BET results clearly show that the MnO x -PC catalyst has an aggregated structure with low porosity and low specific surface area of 8.15m2 g−1. Compared to this, the MnO x -HT catalyst has a developed ordered mesoporous structure and a high surface specific area of about 9 times higher than that of the MnO x -PC catalyst. Besides, the adsorption capacity of the MnO x -HT catalyst increases tremendously, as confirmed by the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm results. Consequently, the reactant molecules such as the PVOCs and O2 molecules readily adsorb onto the MnO x -HT catalyst. This can obviously promote the catalytic combustion of the gaseous reactant molecules on the MnO x -HT catalyst. In addition to this effect, the ordered mesoporous structure of the MnO x -HT catalyst facilitates the migration and diffusion of the reactant and product molecules in the porous structure. These superior structural properties of the MnO x -HT catalyst can provide a favorable environment for the catalytic combustion of PVOCs at lower reaction temperature than that of MnOx-PC. In nutshell, the appropriate chemical composition and exceptional structural properties of the MnO x -HT catalyst account for its improved catalytic activity towards PVOCs. Meanwhile, the catalytic combustion of benzene over the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts does not exceed 70% in the studied reaction temperature range, and catalytic combustion properties of benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene are different from each other, as shown in Fig. 7a and b. This is not only attributed to the physicochemical properties of the prepared MnO x catalysts, but is also related to the inherent characteristics of the PVOCs. In principle, the behavior of the VOCs during the catalytic combustion is determined by various factors, including the strength of adsorption, structural stability, and the strength of the weakest CH bond [33–35]. As a matter of fact, both the methyl and ethyl groups are electron donors. Structurally, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene are generated by replacing the hydrogen atoms in the benzene ring with methyl or ethyl groups. The electron density of these compounds is typically higher than that of the benzene. Consequently, during the catalytic combustion, the stable aromatic ring of benzene is directly destroyed, and the molecular polarity of toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene is greatly altered [35]. In addition, the solid metal oxide catalysts have strong surface polarity due to the existence of the metaloxygen chemical bonds with strong polarity. This facilitates the adsorption of molecules with polarity. Therefore, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene molecules with polarity are readily adsorbed and activated by the MnO x catalysts and are more easily oxidized than the benzene molecules [33,36]. Obviously, in this study, the catalytic combustion of toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene molecules are higher than the benzene molecules. The molecular dimensions of benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene molecules are 4.97Ǻ, 5.83Ǻ, 6.68Ǻ, and 5.92Ǻ, respectively [37]. The catalytic combustion of xylene, ethylbenzene, toluene, and benzene over the MnO x -HT catalyst follows the order of their molecular dimensions. The results obtained in this study indicate that the PVOC molecules with large molecular dimension can easily undergo catalytic combustion on the ordered mesoporous MnO x -HT catalyst. According to the TEM and BET analysis, the pore size of the MnO x -HT catalyst is closer to the molecular dimension of xylene and ethylbenzene. This facilitates effective adsorption and activation of the xylene and ethylbenzene molecules on the catalyst surface. On the other hand, the molecular dimension of benzene and toluene is smaller than the pore size of the catalyst. Consequently, the benzene and toluene molecules tend to diffuse and migrate freely in or/and out the ordered mesoporous structure, without effective adsorption onto the surface of the catalyst. Therefore, the catalytic combustion activity of the investigated PVOCs over the MnO x -HT catalyst complies with the following order: xylene>ethylbenzene>toluene>benzene. On the other hand, in case of the MnO x -PC catalyst, the phenyl compound molecules are mainly adsorbed and activated outside the catalyst surface because of its low specific surface area and low porosity. Under this situation, the PVOC molecules with large molecular dimension cannot be easily adsorbed and activated by the MnO x -PC catalyst because of the steric-hindrance effect. Therefore, the xylene and ethylbenzene molecules undergo catalytic combustion at higher reaction temperature when compared with the toluene and benzene molecules. 3.8 Determination of toluene catalytic combustion stability The stability of the prepared catalysts during the catalytic combustion of toluene was investigated by controlling the reaction time in the range of 600min. The corresponding results for the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts are shown in Fig. 8a and b, respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 8a, the combustion of toluene over the MnO x -HT catalyst occurs quickly from 20.5% to 0 within 11min at 205°C. At the temperature of 210°C, the catalytic combustion of toluene reaches 99.8% at the initial stage of reaction, and stably maintains above 97.0% for 600min. Similarly, the toluene conversion over the MnO x -PC catalyst reduces quickly from 13.0% to 0 within about 7min at 285°C, as shown in Fig. 8b. At the temperature of 290°C, the catalytic conversion of toluene decreases from 99.1% to 96.5% within the initial 4min of reaction, and then maintains above 95.0% for 600min. These results clearly demonstrate that the toluene combustion does not occur over the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts at 205°C and 285°C, respectively. Considering the experimental condition adopted in this study, the observed low conversion can be attributed to the adsorption of toluene molecules on the surface of the catalysts. The MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts exhibit high catalytic stability for toluene combustion at 210°C and 290°C, respectively. This result indicates that both the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts exhibit high catalytic stability towards the combustion of toluene. The high stability is attributed to the perfect trade-off between the “supply” and the “consumption” of reactive oxygen species, as facilitated by the high content of surface reactive oxygen and oxygen mobility of the MnO x oxide catalysts. This leads to the effective adsorption and activation of molecular O2 on the surface of the catalyst, which provides surplus reactive oxygen for the complete oxidation of toluene. The high stability is once again related to the composition and structure of the prepared MnO x oxide catalysts [14]. Therefore, the superior structure and stable composition of the MnO x -HT catalyst facilitated the conversion of molecular oxygen from air to continuously provide sufficient reactive oxygen for the efficient combustion of toluene, at relatively lower temperature during the long reaction time. 4 Conclusions In summary, MnO x catalysts were synthesized by hard template and precipitation methods and their catalytic performance was evaluated towards various PVOCs, including benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene. Systematic characterization of the samples clearly indicates that the physicochemical properties of the prepared MnO x oxide catalysts are significantly affected by the preparation methods. The MnO x -HT catalyst, which was prepared using KIT-6 as the structure-directing hard template, has a highly ordered mesoporous structure with a high specific surface area of 87.9m2 g−1. At the same time, the MnO x -HT catalyst has a higher content of MnO2 species, more MnO x species in the well-dispersed or amorphous state, higher content of surface-adsorbed oxygen, better oxygen mobility, and low-temperature reducibility than the MnO x -PC catalyst prepared by precipitation method. The T 90 corresponding to the catalytic combustion of xylene, ethylbenzene and toluene, and the T 60 of benzene over the MnO x -HT catalyst are 200°C, 205°C, 210°C, and 225°C, respectively, following the order xylene>ethylbenzene>toluene>benzene. Similarly, the T 90 corresponding to the catalytic combustion of xylene, ethylbenzene, toluene, and the T 60 of benzene over the MnO x -PC catalyst are 280°C, 290°C, 280°C, and 275°C, respectively. In addition, both the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts exhibit high stability towards the catalytic combustion of toluene. This could be attributed to their ability to continuously provide sufficient reactive oxygen species for combustion of PVOCs at the specified reaction temperature. The catalytic performance of the MnO x catalysts is mainly affected by their chemical composition and structure, or more specifically, the dispersion and chemical state of MnO x , mesoporous structure, content of surface exposed atoms, content of surface adsorbed oxygen molecules, oxygen mobility, and reducibility. Besides, the inherent physicochemical properties of the phenyl compounds also influence their catalytic combustion. coredata.dc:description: In this study, manganese oxide (MnO x ) catalysts were prepared by using hard-template (MnO x -HT) and precipitation (MnO x -PC) methods. The prepared MnO x catalysts were systematically characterized by XRD, TEM, BET, XPS, O2-TPD, and H2-TPR analyses. The activity of the catalysts was investigated in the catalytic combustion of PVOCs, such as benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene, in air. Results indicate that the chemical composition and structure of the prepared MnO x oxide catalysts are obviously affected by the preparation methods. The T 90 corresponding to the catalytic combustion of xylene, ethylbenzene, toluene, and the T 60 of benzene over the MnO x -HT catalyst are 200°C, 205°C, 210°C, and 225°C, which are much lower than that over MnO x -PC. The catalytic combustion of the PVOCs over the MnO x -HT catalyst follows the order xylene>ethylbenzene>toluene>benzene. Both the MnO x -HT and MnO x -PC catalysts exhibit stable catalytic performance during the combustion of toluene. Therefore, the superior catalytic performance of the MnO x -HT catalyst can be attributed to the high MnO2 content, high concentration of surface reactive oxygen, highly ordered mesopores, large specific surface area, good oxygen mobility, and low-temperature reducibility. In addition, the catalytic combustion of the phenyl compounds is affected by their inherent characteristics such as structural stability, molecular polarity, and dimensions.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic combustion of PVOCs on MnO x catalysts
